ygData.subject: Re: Polychronization
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Oliver, ... I completely agree. This is also my opinion about the things we should look for when we develop neural networks. In my case it was the article

Subject: Re: Polychronization
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=543004838; y=asw-L8PXiadGblMzkt6U1S6eWdstylF1eIW6IQx41mlpo-L_TUA7aLS0gsxLaJMemRRa8Xqw-TNay2k
X-Yahoo-Profile: martin_pyka

Hi Oliver,

> 
> Yes! I'm fascinated by this ability of brain regions to me=
aningfully
> process whatever input types they are presented with, it seems=
 quite
> incredible, and I think points to something fundamental about how =
(at least
> some regions of) natural neural networks operate. 

I completel=
y agree. This is also my opinion about the things we should look for when w=
e develop neural networks. In my case it was the article "Evolution of decl=
arative memory" (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079) which outline=
s the adaptiveness of the hippocampus and highlights that an evolutionary p=
erspective on certain brain regions is necessary to understand their genera=
l function. This and some other articles are the reason why I focus now on =
learning of sequential information. 

> 
> Can you provide some links to pu=
blications or other information about the
> "Brain in a box" model and the =
related CPPN encoding?

I send you an email. But I will upload this article=
 soon on my webpage as well.

> 
> There's a "Software" tab at the top of t=
he website, I should have been more
> specific, sorry. Direct link: http://=
ojcoleman.com/content/software

Ok, so you implemented everything in Java. =
I mostly work in Matlab and Python. 

> 
> I'm also planning on using the I=
zhikevich neuron model (so computationally
> fast with such rich and appare=
ntly realistic dynamics!). 

For my latest research I programmed a lot usin=
g the Izhikevich neuron and heterogeneous conduction delays (based on the s=
cripts provided by Izhikevich in the Polychronization paper). Just in case =
you need more flexibility in setting up the topology of the network and cal=
culating all the auxiliary variables I have solved all these problems (in M=
atlab ;)) and can send you the code.

I was planning on
> trying out some m=
odel of synaptogenesis but haven't yet got around to
> looking at models; 
=

Are you also looking for implementing a certain function within your model=
 or are you more interested in the mechanisms that lead to the formation of=
 a network architecture? 

> > With a colleague, we work on a model that im=
plements structural
> > plasticity, heterogeneous conduction delays and STD=
P in spiking neurons (we
> > use the Izhikevich neuron and everything is im=
plemented in Matlab).
> > Synapses are build depending on the activation le=
vel of the neuron and its
> > projection kernel. I think, the projection ke=
rnel could be something that
> > can be encoded by a CPPN. 

> I'd be inter=
ested in learning more about your model (and
> why you're using that partic=
ular model). What is the "projection kernel"?
> What prompted you to look a=
t synaptogenesis?

The model has been developed by Markus Butz (e.g. http:/=
/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/191620729) who is interested in structural pla=
sticity. Together, we extended it by heterogeneous conduction delays and ST=
DP (like in the polychronization paper). The model designed by Markus is pa=
rticularly suitable to model and explain experimental data from lesion stud=
ies (especially in visual cortices). The "projection kernel" is basically a=
 probability distribution across space that determines where potential axon=
s and and dendrites build synapses. The formation of new synapses is determ=
ined according to this kernel and the activity level of the neurons. (maybe=
 I should invite Markus to join this discussion here, he can explain more a=
bout it). I think the kernel is something which could be perfectly evolved =
using CPPNs.

It was mainly the work of Markus that convinced me that synap=
togenesis is an important factor in the development of neural networks and =
especially interesting for Artificial Development because having these self=
-organizing mechanisms should make it easier for the encoding to generate r=
obust neural networks.

> > Having this kind of super-gun, we are now facin=
g
> > the question: how to setup an appropriate fitness-function, which run=
s a
> > bit into the discussions we had here the last weeks. :-)
> 
> Are y=
ou looking for tasks/problems/environments to try your model on, or
> are y=
ou just not sure how to set up a fitness function for a task you've
> decid=
ed on?

We are working on some tasks/problems for the model. Besides some p=
henomenons in the visual cortex we are looking at, I am in particular wonde=
ring how a model of the hippocampus might look like that is able to learn a=
nd recognize sequences of information.

In your blog postings you write tha=
t you are also interested in learning mechanisms. I would like to know more=
 about your project. Do you have already a certain task or function in mind=
 you are going to implement? 

Best,
Martin
